articles.headline: Vladimir Putin, Family Man
articles.snippet: As Western nations place sanctions on people close to the Russian leader, including family members, the strict secrecy surrounding his private life is being punctured.
articles.abstract: As Western nations place sanctions on people close to the Russian leader, including family members, the strict secrecy surrounding his private life is being punctured.
articles.lead_paragraph: VOORSCHOTEN, Netherlands — Vladimir Putin did not like the prying.

articles.headline: The Stock Market, After Soaring for Years, Returns to Earth
articles.snippet: The market has been producing double-digit returns for investors, even at moments of great national strife. But the party has ended and it may be a long time before it begins again.
articles.abstract: The market has been producing double-digit returns for investors, even at moments of great national strife. But the party has ended and it may be a long time before it begins again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until very recently, the stock market seemed to defy gravity, producing double-digit returns that provided many Americans with financial comfort even as everything else crumbled around them.

articles.headline: New Biden Administration Rules for Charter Schools Spur Bipartisan Backlash
articles.snippet: Critics of the proposal say the rules are overly restrictive and would stymie the growth of charter schools, whose 3.6 million students are largely Black and Hispanic.
articles.abstract: Critics of the proposal say the rules are overly restrictive and would stymie the growth of charter schools, whose 3.6 million students are largely Black and Hispanic.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — New rules proposed by the Education Department to govern a federal grant program for charter schools are drawing bipartisan backlash and angering parents, who say the Biden administration is seeking to stymie schools that have fallen out of favor with many Democrats but maintain strong support among Black and Latino families.

articles.headline: Israeli Police Attack Mourners Before Funeral for Palestinian American Journalist
articles.snippet: As hundreds gathered to witness the start of Shireen Abu Akleh’s funeral procession, riot police assaulted the people carrying her coffin.
articles.abstract: As hundreds gathered to witness the start of Shireen Abu Akleh’s funeral procession, riot police assaulted the people carrying her coffin.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In life, Shireen Abu Akleh, an acclaimed Palestinian American broadcaster, was one of the leading chroniclers of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Raja Abdulrahim

articles.headline: West Increases Pressure on Putin, Including Sanctions on Reputed Girlfriend
articles.snippet: The Russian leader was challenged by the prospect of an enlarged NATO, plans to get Ukrainian grain exports past a Kremlin blockade, and sanctions on his purported mistress.
articles.abstract: The Russian leader was challenged by the prospect of an enlarged NATO, plans to get Ukrainian grain exports past a Kremlin blockade, and sanctions on his purported mistress.
articles.lead_paragraph: KRAKOW, Poland — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia faced fresh setbacks Friday over the Ukraine invasion, as Sweden became the second neutral country in two days to move toward joining NATO and the West devised ways to reroute Ukrainian grain past a Russian naval blockade.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora, Mark Landler and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: A Crypto Emperor’s Vision: No Pants, His Rules
articles.snippet: Sam Bankman-Fried is a studiously disheveled billionaire who made a fortune overseeing trades that are too risky for the U.S. market. Now he wants Washington to follow his lead.
articles.abstract: Sam Bankman-Fried is a studiously disheveled billionaire who made a fortune overseeing trades that are too risky for the U.S. market. Now he wants Washington to follow his lead.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASSAU, The Bahamas — The crypto executive Sam Bankman-Fried, who rose to fame by building a $40 billion business in less than three years, stood in the wings at the Baha Mar convention center, wearing his usual schlubby ensemble of shorts and a T-shirt. He was about to take the stage with Anthony Scaramucci, a former White House communications director who rose to fame by losing that job in less than two weeks.

articles.headline: Business Travel Resumes, Though Not at Its Former Pace
articles.snippet: Domestic travel has returned faster than international. And some destinations like Las Vegas are rebounding more quickly than big cities like New York.
articles.abstract: Domestic travel has returned faster than international. And some destinations like Las Vegas are rebounding more quickly than big cities like New York.
articles.lead_paragraph: Business travel appears to be returning, albeit unevenly, after all but disappearing for most of the pandemic.

articles.headline: The Tesla Effect: Snowmobiles, Boats and Mowers Go Electric
articles.snippet: They’re quieter and better for the climate. But snow and water create new technological challenges for designers.
articles.abstract: They’re quieter and better for the climate. But snow and water create new technological challenges for designers.
articles.lead_paragraph: STOWE, Vt. — Snowmobiles are part of the winter soundtrack in this part of Vermont, at their worst shattering the stillness of the forest like motorcycles on skis. But the motorized sleds bouncing along a wooded mountain trail in February were silent except for the whoosh of metal runners on snow.

articles.headline: Facing Higher Grocery Prices, Shoppers Change Habits
articles.snippet: They’re store-hopping, cutting back on expensive items and using more coupons. Plying the meat counter staff with homemade banana bread for favors is not out of the question.
articles.abstract: They’re store-hopping, cutting back on expensive items and using more coupons. Plying the meat counter staff with homemade banana bread for favors is not out of the question.
articles.lead_paragraph: Susan Pollack, a property manager who was shopping one afternoon last week at a Costco in Marina del Rey, Calif., said she was startled that the price of a bulk pack of toilet paper had surged from $17 to $25.
articles.byline: By Maria Cramer, Christine Hauser and Livia Albeck-Ripka

articles.headline: How Australia Saved Thousands of Lives While Covid Killed a Million Americans
articles.snippet: The United States and Australia share similar demographics, but their pandemic death rates point to very different cultures of trust.
articles.abstract: The United States and Australia share similar demographics, but their pandemic death rates point to very different cultures of trust.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: A Fringe Conspiracy Theory, Fostered Online, Is Refashioned by the G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Replacement theory, espoused by the suspect in the Buffalo massacre, has been embraced by some right-wing politicians and commentators.
articles.abstract: Replacement theory, espoused by the suspect in the Buffalo massacre, has been embraced by some right-wing politicians and commentators.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside a Pittsburgh synagogue in 2018, a white man with a history of antisemitic internet posts gunned down 11 worshipers, blaming Jews for allowing immigrant “invaders” into the United States.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Karen Yourish

articles.headline: In Rebirth for NATO, Europe Unites in Face of Putin’s Ambition
articles.snippet: Sweden’s and Finland’s embrace of NATO after decades of neutrality is a clear statement that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has ended an era of European illusions about Moscow.
articles.abstract: Sweden’s and Finland’s embrace of NATO after decades of neutrality is a clear statement that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has ended an era of European illusions about Moscow.
articles.lead_paragraph: The decisions by Finland and Sweden to abandon the neutrality they adhered to for decades and apply to join NATO is the strongest indication yet of a profound change in Europe in the face of an aggressive Russian imperial project.

articles.headline: Madison Avenue’s Biggest Event Returns, to a Whole New World
articles.snippet: In the three years since the television industry’s biggest companies pitched their shows to advertisers in person at the so-called upfronts, the entertainment industry has been flipped on its head.
articles.abstract: In the three years since the television industry’s biggest companies pitched their shows to advertisers in person at the so-called upfronts, the entertainment industry has been flipped on its head.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the first time in three years, the circus is coming back to town.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and John Koblin

articles.headline: The Little Red Boxes Making a Mockery of Campaign Finance Laws
articles.snippet: Democratic candidates are all-but scripting ads for super PACs and dark-money groups to do their bidding — in plain sight.
articles.abstract: Democratic candidates are all-but scripting ads for super PACs and dark-money groups to do their bidding — in plain sight.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facing a threat from his left flank, Representative Kurt Schrader of Oregon wanted to send an urgent message to allies ahead of his upcoming primary: It was time to go on the attack.

articles.headline: Yellen Looks to Get Global Tax Deal Back on Track During Europe Trip
articles.snippet: The Treasury secretary is traveling to Warsaw, Brussels and Bonn, Germany, this week at an uncertain time for the global economy.
articles.abstract: The Treasury secretary is traveling to Warsaw, Brussels and Bonn, Germany, this week at an uncertain time for the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen arrived in Europe this week to join U.S. allies in confronting multiple threats to the world economy: Russia’s war in Ukraine, soaring inflation and food shortages.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: The West’s Scramble for Gas Could Enrich and Empower Tiny Qatar
articles.snippet: As the United States and Europe seek to deprive Russia of its oil and gas income, their leaders hope Qatar can help fill the void.
articles.abstract: As the United States and Europe seek to deprive Russia of its oil and gas income, their leaders hope Qatar can help fill the void.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAS LAFFAN INDUSTRIAL CITY, Qatar — Over the past quarter-century, the tiny Persian Gulf state of Qatar has dispatched increasing amounts of natural gas to a growing list of customers around the world, amassing profound wealth and acquiring a geopolitical importance it would otherwise lack.

articles.headline: Are You Happy? Your Boss Is Asking.
articles.snippet: To some, the pursuit of workplace happiness — and its price, like an $18,000 “happiness M.B.A.” for managers — can seem like a corporate attempt to turn feelings into productivity.
articles.abstract: To some, the pursuit of workplace happiness — and its price, like an $18,000 “happiness M.B.A.” for managers — can seem like a corporate attempt to turn feelings into productivity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Garry Ridge, who runs the chemical company WD-40, has a leadership style guided by two sources — Aristotle, and the BlackRock chief executive Larry Fink.

articles.headline: Renault strikes a deal to exit Russia, for now.
articles.snippet: The French company will sell its stake in Russia’s largest automaker for one ruble, with the option of returning within six years.
articles.abstract: The French company will sell its stake in Russia’s largest automaker for one ruble, with the option of returning within six years.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French automaker Renault announced Monday that it was exiting Russia in a deal negotiated with the Russian government that would allow Renault the option of resuming business in the country at a future date.
